div1.head: Military Orders regarding Guy Charles Moore Godfrey, May 2, 1904
div1.p:
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES
* 1934 *
[unclear]

THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.

RECORDS OF THE WAR DEPARTMENT, Office of the Surgeon
General, Register of Medical Officers, Volume 11.

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT
OF THE COLORADO,
Denver, Colorado, May 2, 1904,

Under the provisions of General Orders, No. 86, Headquarters
of the Army, series 1902, the following named officer and enlisted
men who on the dates and at the places specified, distinguished
themselves by specially meritorious acts, are accorded honorable
mention:
✓

Godfrey, Guy C. M., assistant surgeon, U. S. Army: For his ex-
emplary act at Fort Apache, Arizona, April 12, 1904, in assisting in
placing 100 pounds of powder underneath a burning building which
it was necessary to destroy in order to control the fire and prevent
further destruction of government property.
✓

Johnson, Sant, corporal, Troop G, 3d Cavalry: For excep-
tionally gallant, hazardous and exemplary conduct at Fort Apache,
Arizona, April 12, 1904, in his voluntary efforts to control a fire by
remaining on a building then burning, and trying to prevent the
spread of the fire till it was necessary to turn the hose on himself
to extinguish the fire in his own clothing, and further in his volun-
tarily assisting in placing 100 pounds of powder underneath the
burning building which it was necessary to destroy in order to con-
trol the fire and prevent further destruction of government prop-
erty.

Wilson, James, corporalSergeant, Troop M, 5th Cavalry: For his exem-
plary conduct at Fort Apache, Arizona, on the afternoon of April
12, 1904, in his efforts to control a fire by remaining on a burning
building under extreme heat and thereby probably saving that
building, and in attempting to reach a second building, passing
through such heat that he fell insensible.

Page, William M., private, Troop G, 3rd Cavalry: For his ex-
emplary conduct at Fort Apache, Arizona, on the afternoon of
April 12, 1904, in his efforts to control a fire, by remaining with
Sergeant James Wilson, Troop M, 5th Cavalry under extreme heat
and attempting to rescue him until he himself was prostrated.

Cooper, William H., private First-Class, Hospital Corps: For
excellent work performed at Fort Apache, Arizona, on the after-
noon of April 12, 1904, in his efforts in tearing down burning
buildings and in otherwise preventing the spread of a fire, in which
work he burned and injured both of his hands.
BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL BALDWIN:

A. C. SHARPE,
Lieutenant Colonel,
Assistant Adjutant General,
Adjutant General.
